35 of 38 people found the following review helpful
5.0 out of 5 stars A book about tools that fills a need in scientific computing
Python For Data Analysis is a book about tools. Python is an excellent general purpose language that has developed some niche applications, science being one of them due to some excellent libraries such as NumPy, SciPy, IPython, Matplotlib, and increasingly Pandas -- which Wes created. Collectively these tools form the basis of the "scientific computing stack" and are...
Read the full review ›
Published 9 months ago by Jason Wirth
› See more 5 star , 4 star reviews

75 of 94 people found the following review helpful
3.0 out of 5 stars dive into pandas and NumPy
Wes McKinney's "Python for Data Analysis" (O'Reilly, 2012) is a tour pandas and NumPy (mostly pandas) for folks looking to crunch "big-ish" data with Python. The target audience is not Pythonistas, but rather scientists, educators, statisticians, financial analysts, and the rest of the "non-programmer" cohort that is finding more and more these days that it needs to do a...
Read the full review ›
Published 9 months ago by R. Friesel Jr.
› See more 3 star , 2 star , 1 star reviews

div.div: 1 of 1 people found the following review helpful

div.span: Finally, I can ditch R and use a language I love , August 6, 2013

div.div:
By
Kyle Bishop - See all my reviews
Amazon Verified Purchase ( What's this? )
This review is from: Python for Data Analysis (Paperback) I've been using Python as my primary language for 10 years on and off, but have been shackled to R for any statistics or graphing for lack of knowledge of the scientific Python environment and no clear place to learn it all. I knew Python would be perfect for data analysis, but never knew where to begin. Because of this book, I can finally say that I am completely R free and loving it!
The book is incredibly well written by the guy that developed the pandas library. He brings his practical data analysis experience into this text and it shines through. Each chapter takes you through the core libraries and tools that you'll need to conduct real data analysis from beginning to end. He is especially sensitive to the realities of handling real world data, which is often messy and needs to be massaged into a usable form, and which Python and its libraries are ridiculously good at handling. The introduction to iPython is perfect for anyone coming from MATLAB/R/etc. that has been missing a lot of the interactive features that those languages offer by default.
You should have at minimum an introductory understanding of Python and statistics, which you likely have if you're the kind of person that would think to pick this book up in the first place. Other than that, this book will teach you how to conduct data analysis in the best possible way with the best possible language.

3.0 out of 5 stars Not Special , June 15, 2013
By
Dan - See all my reviews
This review is from: Python for Data Analysis (Paperback) I have been working with python and data analysis for over a year which means building a database, creating and manipulating numpy matrixes, doing linear and logistic regression the data. I skimmed this book for half an hour in the bookstore it looks like it may be slightly helpful to have around but most of it seemed pretty straight forward as stuff I already knew and this book definitely did not jump out to me as a must have.

4.0 out of 5 stars Good Tutorial / Reference for Quant Finance Types , June 15, 2013
By
Anthony Patsicostas - See all my reviews
Amazon Verified Purchase ( What's this? )
This review is from: Python for Data Analysis (Paperback) It's a good start if you need to learn python for your job. I work in financial services and a lot of the issues I tend to run into are touched upon and solved in this book. Wes was an analyst himself when he developed pandas so it makes sense he feels my pain when it comes to data. Also it's fairly accessible to even lay people, which is somewhat of a departure from other books O'Reilly publishes.
One major suggestion is to publish this book in color. The visualization capabilities that are standard with pylab are stunning and greyscale photos don't do them justice.

5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Book! , May 16, 2013
By
rpv (California) - See all my reviews
(TOP 500 REVIEWER)
This review is from: Python for Data Analysis (Paperback) if you love data, lots of data, analyzing them, visualizing them, writing programs to interpret them this book is a treat. Big data is a rage these days (2013), so if you have lots of data to analyze this book has lots of techniques. Shows examples of plotting data using native methods, matplotlib, NumPy library etc. Applications analyzed include election data, economic/financial data like stock price trends.
Definitely a worthy book for students and professionals alike. I would have like map/GPS data analysis and visualization as it represents huge data, but which does not change over time. It will cool to develop a GPS mapping app/mashing app using python and its libraries.

4.0 out of 5 stars Interesting book on data analysis using the panda library , May 14, 2013
By
Timothy Lovett (Tampa, FL) - See all my reviews
(VINE VOICE) (REAL NAME)
This review is from: Python for Data Analysis (Paperback)
Customer review from the Amazon Vine Program ( What's this? ) I'm not a scientist nor really a python programmer. I've programmed in many other languages but my experiences with python were mostly around the twisted engine for networking code. The book covers python in the appendix to some degree but it's not really a good source for data on the python language itself (which should be expected). I found the information to be digestible even with my limited knowledge of the subject matter. As others mentioned the book mainly covers the panda library for data analysis.
I'd suggest the book to non programmers interested in data analysis. I think it may be worth looking into a beginners python tutorial online before reading the book, however, as I mentioned above the language is only briefly covered in the appendix.
